column2: At last, after traveling two days and a night, they arrived at Boulogne toward the evening, favored by magnificent weather.

column3: Boulogne was a strong position, then almost a deserted town, built entirely on the heights; what is now called the lower town did not then exist.

column3: Gentlemen, said De Winter, on reaching the gate of the town, "let us do here as at Paris-let us separate to avoid suspicion.

column2: I know an inn, little frequented, but of which the host is entirely devoted to me.

column2: I will go there, where I expect to find letters, and you go to the first tavern in the town, to L'Epee du Grand Henri for instance, refresh yourselves, and in two hours be upon the jetty; our boat is waiting for us there."

column2: Their horses were fed, but not unsaddled; the grooms supped, for it was already late, and their two masters, impatient to return, appointed a place of meeting with them on the jetty and desired them on no account to exchange a word with any one.

column2: Athos and Aramis walked down toward the port.

column2: From their dress, covered with dust, and from a certain easy manner by means of which a man accustomed to travel is always recognizable, the two friends excited the attention of a few promenaders.

column2: This man, whom they had noticed from the first for the same reason they had themselves been remarked by others, was walking in a listless way up and down the jetty. From the moment he perceived them he did not cease to look at them and seemed to burn with the wish to speak to them.

column2: That is doubtless our boat, said Athos.

column2: Hush! said Athos, "we are overheard."

column2: Gentlemen, said the man, who was young and pale, bowing with ease and courtesy, "pardon my curiosity, but I see you come from Paris, or at least that you are strangers at Boulogne."
column3: Gentlemen, said the man, who was young and pale, bowing with ease and courtesy, "pardon my curiosity, but I see you come from Paris, or at least that you are strangers at Boulogne."

column2: We come from Paris, yes, replied Athos, with the same courtesy; "what is there we can do for you?"
column3: We come from Paris, yes, replied Athos, with the same courtesy; "what is there we can do for you?"

column2: Sir, said the young man, "will you be so good as to tell me if it be true that Cardinal Mazarin is no longer minister?"
column3: Sir, said the young man, "will you be so good as to tell me if it be true that Cardinal Mazarin is no longer minister?"

column2: That is a strange question, said Aramis.
column3: That is a strange question, said Aramis.

column2: He is and he is not, replied Athos; "that is to say, he is dismissed by one-half of France, but by intrigues and promises he makes the other half sustain him; you will perceive that this may last a long time."
column3: He is and he is not, replied Athos; "that is to say, he is dismissed by one half of France, but by intrigues and promises he makes the other half sustain him; you will perceive that this may last a long time."

column2: However, sir, said the stranger, "he has neither fled nor is in prison?"
column3: However, sir, said the stranger, "he has neither fled nor is in prison?"

column2: No, sir, not at this moment at least.
column3: No, sir, not at this moment at least.

column2: What do you think of that interrogator? asked Aramis.
column3: What do you think of that interrogator? asked Aramis.

column2: I think he is either a dull provincial person or a spy in search of information.
column3: I think he is either a dull provincial person or a spy in search of information.

column2: And you replied to him with that notion?
column3: And you replied to him with that notion?

column2: Nothing warranted me to answer him otherwise; he was polite to me and I was so to him.
column3: Nothing warranted me to answer him otherwise; he was polite to me and I was so to him.

column3: But if he be a spy----

column2: We are not living in the time of Cardinal Richelieu, who would have closed the ports on bare suspicion."

column2: And since when have you become afraid of a quarrel?

column2: Aramis, you will certainly laugh at me, you will say that I am always repeating the same thing, you will call me the most timorous of visionaries; but to whom do you see a resemblance in that young man?

column3: Diable! resumed Aramis, "I have little fancy for the sea by day, still less at night; the sounds of wind and wave, the frightful movements of the vessel; I confess I prefer the convent of Noisy."

column3: They saw him in the distance climbing the rock in order to look down upon the boat as it passed.

column2: Ay, but, said Aramis, "that young fellow is decidedly a spy."
column3: Ay, but, said Aramis, "that young fellow is decidedly a spy."

column2: Which is the young man? asked De Winter, turning around.
column3: Which is the young man? asked De Winter, turning around.

column2: He who followed us and spoke to us awaits us there; behold!
column3: He who followed us and spoke to us awaits us there; behold!

column2: De Winter turned and followed the direction of Aramis's finger.
column3: De Winter turned and followed the direction of Aramis's finger.

column2: The beacon bathed with light the little strait through which they were about to pass and the rock where the young man stood with bare head and crossed arms.
column3: The beacon bathed with light the little strait through which they were about to pass and the rock where the young man stood with bare head and crossed arms.

column2: It is he! exclaimed De Winter, seizing the arm of Athos; "it is he!
column3: It is he! exclaimed De Winter, seizing the arm of Athos; "it is he!

column2: I thought I recognized him and I was not mistaken."
column3: I thought I recognized him and I was not mistaken."

column2: Whom do you mean? asked Aramis.
column3: Whom do you mean? asked Aramis.

column2: Milady's son, replied Athos.
column3: Milady's son, replied Athos.

column2: The monk! exclaimed Grimaud.
column3: The monk! exclaimed Grimaud.

column2: The young man heard these words and bent so forward over the rock that one might have supposed he was about to precipitate himself from it.
column3: The young man heard these words and bent so forward over the rock that one might have supposed he was about to precipitate himself from it.

column2: Yes, it is I, my uncle--I, the son of Milady--I, the monk--I, the secretary and friend of Cromwell--I know you now, both you and your companions.
column3: Yes, it is I, my uncle-I, the son of Milady-I, the monk-I, the secretary and friend of Cromwell-I know you now, both you and your companions.

column2: In that boat sat three men, unquestionably brave, whose courage no man would have dared dispute; nevertheless, at that voice, that accent and those gestures, they felt a chill access of terror cramp their veins.
column3: In that boat sat three men, unquestionably brave, whose courage no man would have dared dispute; nevertheless, at that voice, that accent and those gestures, they felt a chill access of terror cramp their veins.

column2: As for Grimaud, his hair stood on end and drops of sweat ran down his brow.
column3: As for Grimaud, his hair stood on end and drops of sweat ran down his brow.

column2: Ah! exclaimed Aramis, "that is the nephew, the monk, and the son of Milady, as he says himself."
column3: Ah! exclaimed Aramis, "that is the nephew, the monk, and the son of Milady, as he says himself."

column2: Alas, yes, murmured De Winter.
column3: Alas, yes, murmured De Winter.

column2: Then wait, said Aramis; and with the terrible coolness which on important occasions he showed, he took one of the muskets from Tony, shouldered and aimed it at the young man, who stood, like the accusing angel, upon the rock.
column3: Then wait, said Aramis; and with the terrible coolness which on important occasions he showed, he took one of the muskets from Tony, shouldered and aimed it at the young man, who stood, like the accusing angel, upon the rock.

column3: Athos threw himself on the muzzle of the gun and arrested the shot which was about to be fired.

column2: The devil take you, said Aramis.
column3: The devil take you, said Aramis.

column2: I had him so well at the point of my gun I should have sent a ball into his breast.
column3: I had him so well at the point of my gun I should have sent a ball into his breast.

column2: It is enough to have killed the mother, said Athos, hoarsely.
column3: It is enough to have killed the mother, said Athos, hoarsely.

column2: The mother was a wretch, who struck at us all and at those dear to us.
column3: The mother was a wretch, who struck at us all and at those dear to us.

column2: Yes, but the son has done us no harm.
column3: Yes, but the son has done us no harm.

column3: Grimaud, who had risen to watch the effect of the shot, fell back hopeless, wringing his hands.

column2: The young man burst into a laugh.
column3: The young man burst into a laugh.

column2: Ah, it is certainly you! he cried.
column3: Ah, it is certainly you! he cried.

column2: I know you even better now.
column3: I know you even better now.

column2: His mocking laugh and threatening words passed over their heads, carried by the breeze, until lost in the depths of the horizon.

column3: Be calm, exclaimed Athos, "for Heaven's sake! have we ceased to be men?"

column2: No, said Aramis, "but that fellow is a fiend; and ask the uncle whether I was wrong to rid him of his dear nephew."
column3: No, said Aramis, "but that fellow is a fiend; and ask the uncle whether I was wrong to rid him of his dear nephew."

column2: De Winter only replied by a groan.
column3: De Winter only replied by a groan.

column2: It was all up with him, continued Aramis; "ah I much fear that with all your wisdom such mercy yet will prove supernal folly."
column3: It was all up with him, continued Aramis; "ah I much fear that with all your wisdom such mercy yet will prove supernal folly."

column2: Athos took Lord de Winter's hand and tried to turn the conversation.
column3: Athos took Lord de Winter's hand and tried to turn the conversation.

column2: When shall we land in England? he asked; but De Winter seemed not to hear his words and made no reply.

column2: See if he is still in the same place."
column3: See if he is still in the same place."

column2: At this moment they were hailed by a voice from the sloop and a few seconds later men, servants and baggage were aboard.
